Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Mesh-Free Monte Carlo Methods for Integrated Simulation of Multi-Scale Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project has its origins in the use of Mesh-free Monte Carlo methods as a novel technology for simulation of multi-physics, multi-scale systems. This project's mesh-free simulation approach is applied to superconducting system design. The lack of engineering tools for integrated analysis and design of superconducting coils, in particular for complex phenomena such as superconducting quench, is a bottleneck that hinders the development of reliable superconducting systems. This project addresses the design and simulation of superconducting devices, enabling reliable, computationally efficient modeling, simulation and analysis of complex phenomena such as quench in full scale systems. Mesh-free modeling tools for multi-physics analysis of multi-scale systems benefit applications where large dimensions or multi-scale geometries makes meshing computationally prohibitive.

This I-Corps project involves software tools and simulation techniques for multi-physics simulation of multi-scale systems based on mesh-free Monte Carlo methods. The approach enables the computationally efficient simulation of coupled systems with multi-scale geometries where proper meshing for conventional finite element methods becomes prohibitive. The project enables a complete study of the potential commercialization of the software tools and simulation techniques being developed, as well as an assessment of technical areas and commercial applications which could benefit from the proposed approach for simulation of multi-scale systems. The project could enable simulation of multi-scale, multi-physics problems in a wide variety of potential applications based on a novel approach: mesh-free floating random walk Monte Carlo methods and may enable simulation of systems that are currently intractable using conventional finite element tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Monte Carlo Methods for Multi-Scale Systems as alternative to conventional FEM tools

Finite element methods (FEM) are universally accepted tools for engineering analysis of physical systems described by partial differential equations in a 3D spatial domain. Highly sophisticated FEM tools are currently available, however:

  • Multi-scale multi-physics systems lead to very large number of elements and impractical simulation times, particularly in transient simulations
  • Conventional FEM is not well posed for parallelization
  • Most end users use similar software tools, therefore their limitations are accepted as normal
  • Engineering analysis and product development has long been done with tools that are not optimal, therefore the motivation to change is not strong in most companies

Monte-Carlo Methods have been presented as having breakthrough potential in the finite-element engineering and analysis market, via mesh-free operation and extensive parallelization based on the use of GPUs (graphics processing units).

This project was dedicated to explore the commercialization potential of Monte Carlo Methods (MCM) as alternative to conventional finite element tools. Monte Carlo Methods can be used to solve multi-dimensional boundary value problems in a 3D domain based on random number generation:

  • MCM can be mesh-free
  • The solution at time n is not needed to calculate the solution at time (n+1)
  • Solution times in FEM grow exponentially with number of elements due to matrix inversion.  That is not the case in a MCM solver.
  • MCM are easily amenable to implement in highly parallel platforms such as GPUs

Scientists and Engineers today extensively use FEM software tools, which have significant limitations: (i) Significant preprocessing effort (meshing), (ii) Long simulation times, in particular in transient analysis, (iii) require to reach a solution over the entire domain, wasting computational effort on regions that are not of interest, and (iv) make limited use of parallelization.

Project Outcomes:   We identified the following need:  In the simulation and scientific analysis market today, there are numerous important problems, in particular multi-physics multi-scale transient problems, that lead to impractical simulation times. The existing state of the art tools (FEM tools) rely on meshing, which often leads to impractical simulation times, or to the practical impossibility of simulating complex events and/or large domains. Mesh-free methods are not available in any of the currently existing tools. Users are highly motivated to find an alternative approach for their simulation needs, but would prefer a product available within their existing tools rather than an entirely new set of tools.

After extensive interviews, this team identified as viable business opportunity the development of a Monte Carlo Engine to replace the conventional finite element solver engine on a commercial software suite. The proposed engine would use highly parallel hardware (GPUs) and use the GUI and post-processing tools from existing FEM suites.

The business opportunity relies on the possibility of developing a new solver engine that would work within existing commercial software tools, leading to a potential breakthrough in simulation times. Such business model would entail a relatively low risk and could start with a relatively modest investment since development of the proposed engine is modular.

The intellectual merit of the proposed approach lies on the development of a general purpose MCM engine solver for the main types of boundary value problems that are highly limited by the use of conventional FEM solvers (heat transfer, electromagnetics, fluid dynamics, nonlinear strain) - this has not been attempted before. The potential broader impacts are not only within the finite element software industry but would open possibilities for scientific analysis and simulation that are not available today.
